    Certainly! To incorporate the data from data.json into the HTML, you'll need to fetch the JSON data and update the HTML structure accordingly. I'll provide a modified version of your code:

    html
    <!DOCTYPE html>
<html lang="en">
<head>
    <meta charset="UTF-8">
    <meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width, initial-scale=1.0">
    <title>Dynamic Cards</title>
    <style>
        /* Add your styling here */
        .card {
            border: 1px solid #ccc;
            padding: 10px;
            margin: 10px;
            text-align: center;
        }

        #showMoreBtn {
            margin-top: 20px;
        }
    </style>
</head>
<body>
    <div id="cardContainer">
        <!-- Initial 6 cards will be dynamically inserted here -->
    </div>
    <button id="showMoreBtn">Show More</button>

    <script>
        const cardContainer = document.getElementById('cardContainer');
        const showMoreBtn = document.getElementById('showMoreBtn');
        let jsonData = []; // To store data from data.json
        let currentIndex = 0;

        function createCard(cardData) {
            const card = document.createElement('div');
            card.classList.add('col-sm-6');
            card.innerHTML = `
                <div class="card sub-body">
                    <div class="sub-body-main-image">
                        <img src="${cardData.img_link}" alt="" class="img-fluid">
                    </div>
                    <div class="card-body">
                        <div>
                            <a href="#" class="main-btn">${cardData.tag_name}</a>
                            <p class="main-text">
                                ${cardData.author_data.full_name} | ${cardData.author_data.job_title} | ${cardData.author_data.read_time} read | ${cardData.author_data.date}
                            </p>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                    <div class="card-footer">
                        <div>
                            <h2>${cardData.title}</h2>
                            <p>${cardData.content}</p>
                        </div>
                    </div>
                </div>
            `;
            cardContainer.appendChild(card);
        }

        async function fetchData() {
            try {
                const response = await fetch('Assets/data.json');
                if (!response.ok) {
                    throw new Error(`Failed to fetch data. Status: ${response.status}`);
                }
                jsonData = await response.json();
                console.log('Fetched JSON data:', jsonData);
                showInitialCards();
            } catch (error) {
                console.error('Error fetching data:', error.message);
            }
        }

        function showInitialCards() {
            for (let i = 0; i < 6 && currentIndex < jsonData.length; i++) {
                createCard(jsonData[currentIndex]);
                currentIndex++;
            }
        }

        function replaceInitialCards() {
            // Remove the initial 6 cards
            for (let i = 0; i < 6; i++) {
                cardContainer.removeChild(cardContainer.firstElementChild);
            }

            // Show the next 10 cards
            for (let i = 0; i < 10 && currentIndex < jsonData.length; i++) {
                createCard(jsonData[currentIndex]);
                currentIndex++;
            }

            // Hide the "Show More" button if all content is exhausted
            if (currentIndex >= jsonData.length) {
                showMoreBtn.style.display = 'none';
            }
        }

        // Show initial 6 cards
        fetchData();

        // Show More button click event
        showMoreBtn.addEventListener('click', function () {
            replaceInitialCards();
        });
    </script>
</body>
</html>

    This code fetches data from data.json and dynamically creates cards using the specified HTML structure. The "Show More" button will continue to load additional cards until all data is exhausted.
